VLDB 2010 , 36th International Conference on Very Large Data Bases
  Singapore : 13 to 17 Sept 2010, Grand Copthorne Waterfront Hotel

Topics of Interest

LayoutNode.Content: VLDB 2010 calls for outstanding research papers as well as proposals for demonstrations. Tutorial and Panel proposals on all topics that will be of particular interest for the community are welcome. VLDB 2010 also strongly encourages the submission of workshop proposals on challenging topics in areas related to the VLDB focus.
LayoutNode.SRC: VLDB 2010 calls for outstanding research papers as well as proposals for demonstrations. Tutorial and Panel proposals on all topics that will be of particular interest for the community are welcome. VLDB 2010 also strongly encourages the submission of workshop proposals on challenging topics in areas related to the VLDB focus.

LayoutNode.Content: VLDB 2010 will be organized into four tracks, each with its own Program Committee:
LayoutNode.SRC: VLDB 2010 will be organized into four tracks, each with its own Program Committee:

LayoutNode.Content: The Core Database Technology Track will evaluate papers on technologies intended to be incorporated within the database system itself. The topics of interest to this track include (but are not limited to):
LayoutNode.SRC: The Core Database Technology Track will evaluate papers on technologies intended to be incorporated within the database system itself. The topics of interest to this track include (but are not limited to):

LayoutNode.Content: Concurrency Control, Recovery and Transaction Management,
LayoutNode.SRC: Concurrency Control, Recovery and Transaction Management,

LayoutNode.Content: The Information Infrastructure Track covers all aspects of data management not implemented within a conventional database engine. The topics covered by this track include (but are not limited to):
LayoutNode.SRC: The Information Infrastructure Track covers all aspects of data management not implemented within a conventional database engine. The topics covered by this track include (but are not limited to):

LayoutNode.Content: Web Services and Web Service Composition,
LayoutNode.SRC: Web Services and Web Service Composition,

LayoutNode.Content: The Industrial, Applications, and Experience Track covers innovative commercial database implementations, novel applications of database technology, and experience in applying recent research advances to practical situations, in any of the following example areas (or, in other areas where data management is important):
LayoutNode.SRC: The Industrial, Applications, and Experience Track covers innovative commercial database implementations, novel applications of database technology, and experience in applying recent research advances to practical situations, in any of the following example areas (or, in other areas where data management is important):

LayoutNode.Content: Adapting DB Technology to Industrial Settings and Requirements,
LayoutNode.SRC: Adapting DB Technology to Industrial Settings and Requirements,

LayoutNode.Content: Application Areas (Government, Finance, Humanities, Telecommunications, Home and Personal Computing, ...),
LayoutNode.SRC: Application Areas (Government, Finance, Humanities, Telecommunications, Home and Personal Computing, ...),

LayoutNode.Content: Business Process Engineering and Execution Support,
LayoutNode.SRC: Business Process Engineering and Execution Support,

LayoutNode.Content: Industrial-Strength Systems based on DB Technology,
LayoutNode.SRC: Industrial-Strength Systems based on DB Technology,

LayoutNode.Content: System Design and Implementation using DB Technology.
LayoutNode.SRC: System Design and Implementation using DB Technology.

LayoutNode.Content: Database management has been an active area of research for several decades. This special topic aims to meet needs for consolidation of a maturing research area by providing a prestigious forum for in-depth analytical or empirical studies and comparisons of existing techniques. The expected contribution of an Experiments and Analyses (E&A) paper is new, independent, comprehensive and reproducible evaluations and comparisons of existing data management techniques. Thus, the intended contribution of an E&A paper is not a new algorithm or technique but rather further insight into the state-of-the-art by means of careful, systematic, and scientific evaluation. Comparisons of algorithmic techniques must either use best-effort re-implementations based on the original papers, or use existing implementations from the original authors, if publicly available. Authors should discuss and validate substantial new results with authors of the original methods before submission.
LayoutNode.SRC: Database management has been an active area of research for several decades. This special topic aims to meet needs for consolidation of a maturing research area by providing a prestigious forum for in-depth analytical or empirical studies and comparisons of existing techniques. The expected contribution of an Experiments and Analyses (E&A) paper is new, independent, comprehensive and reproducible evaluations and comparisons of existing data management techniques. Thus, the intended contribution of an E&A paper is not a new algorithm or technique but rather further insight into the state-of-the-art by means of careful, systematic, and scientific evaluation. Comparisons of algorithmic techniques must either use best-effort re-implementations based on the original papers, or use existing implementations from the original authors, if publicly available. Authors should discuss and validate substantial new results with authors of the original methods before submission.

LayoutNode.Content: The program committee may require accepted papers to include feedback from original authors as a condition of final acceptance.
LayoutNode.SRC: The program committee may require accepted papers to include feedback from original authors as a condition of final acceptance.

LayoutNode.Content: In some cases, material might cut across more than one of the tracks, and indeed we strongly encourage papers that pursue some of the ties between them. As submissions will be judged by their appropriateness for the track in which they are being evaluated, appropriate placement of papers is important. If in doubt, please contact one of the PC chairs. The program committee reserves the right to move papers between the PCs to ensure the fairest possible evaluation.
